questions.text: In what country was origami invented?
questions.explanation:
China.

	Yes, just as the Chinese invented paper, they also invented paperfolding.

questions.text: In what country was origami developed into a fine art?
questions.explanation:
Japan.

	The Japanese developed origami into a wondrous art form.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT usually considered to be a rule of 'traditional' origami?
options: Never cut the paper with scissors
Use only one square per model
questions.explanation:
No colored paper allowed.

	However, many origami artists think these rules originated in the West, not in Japan! I've noticed that in my collection, the Western books stick to the "traditional" rules, while the Japanese books use all kinds of cutting, pasting, odd paper shapes, etc.

questions.text: What is a fold called where you fold the paper towards you?
questions.explanation:
Valley fold.

	Most of the origami folds have specific names.

questions.text: What is the fold called where you fold the paper away from you?
questions.explanation:
Mountain fold.

	Other origami folds include the rabbit-ear fold, petal fold, squash fold and reverse fold.

questions.text: Many origami models start from folded configurations known as 'bases.' Many models can be made from one base. Which of the following is not a base?
questions.explanation:
Horse base.

	Each base is named after a model that can be folded from it.

questions.text: Perhaps the most famous origami model is a depiction of what animal?
questions.explanation:
Crane.

	The crane, also known as the 'flapping bird', is an easy model to fold.

questions.text: What base is used to make the most popular origami animal model?
questions.explanation:
Bird base.

	Making the bird base is the hardest part- it only takes 4 folds after that to make the crane.

questions.text: Some origami models are made up of many pieces folded and then joined together. What is this style of origami called?
questions.explanation:
Modular origami.

	The figures produced are usually geometric models.

questions.text: The Moors independently developed a school of geometric paperfolding. What country adopted this art, terming it 'papiroflexia'?
questions.explanation:
Spain.

	Spain has produced some very inventive paperfolders.
